alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for employee liabilities and indemnity insurance
body:
$!As an employer, you might have to report the costs of employee liabilities and indemnity insurance you provide for your employees. You don't have to pay tax or National Insurance on these costs.$!

Employee liabilities and indemnity insurance covers your employees if someone takes them to court because of a mistake they make at work.

##What to report
What you must report depends on how much an employee or director earns.

Who gets the benefit | What to do | What to deduct or pay
 - | - | -
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate “at a rate”) of less than £8,500 a year | Nothing | Nothing
Employees earning [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate “at a rate”) of £8,500 or more a year | Report on form P11D, section M (unless you have a [dispensation](/apply-for-a-dispensation "Apply for a dispensation")) | Nothing
Directors | Report on form P11D, section M (unless you have a [dispensation](/apply-for-a-dispensation "Apply for a dispensation")) | Nothing

Include the total cost to you of the legal or insurance expenses for each employee.

##Technical guidance

The following guides contain more detailed information:

+ [directors' and officers' liabilities](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/eimanual/eim30500.htm "Directors' and officers' liabilities"){:rel="external"}

+ [employee liability insurance](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/manuals/nimmanual/nim05660.htm "Employee liability insurance"){:rel="external"}

*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
